t:t.t:p: Assume you're declarer at seven hearts, and West leads the jack of diamonds. How would you play the hand?
You will have to play well to justify your optimism in bidding the grand slam. At first glance, it seems the only way to avoid a diamond loser is to try a spade finesse and hope West has the king.

As can be seen, the spade finesse -- a straight 50-50 shot -- would not meet with great success on this occasion. But when you consider your options more carefully, you come to the conclusion that if the opposing trumps are divided 3-2 -- a 68 percent probability -- you can make the slam without risking the spade finesse.

Accordingly, after the queen of diamonds is covered by East's king at trick one, you take the ace, lead a spade to the ace and ruff a spade with the queen. The five of hearts is then led to the eight, and another spade is ruffed with the king.
You next lead the ten of hearts to the jack and ruff the queen of spades with the ace. A club to dummy's jack then allows you to draw the missing trump with the nine.

It is on this trick that the plan you formulated at the beginning comes to fruition. Since you have no more trumps in your hand -- having ruffed three spades with the A-K-Q and used the other two trumps as entries to dummy -- you are able to discard your diamond loser on the nine of hearts!

The last four tricks are taken with the A-K-Q-10 of clubs to make the grand slam. Your 13 tricks consist of the spade and diamond aces, five clubs, three trump tricks in dummy and three spade ruffs in your hand. They're there from the start as long as the trumps divide normally.
